user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of try_get_value:
```c
static void
try_get_value (const char *buf,
               const char *key,
               char **destination)
{
  const char *spos;
  const char *bpos;
  const char *endv;
  size_t klen;
  size_t vlen;

  if (NULL != *destination)
    return;
  bpos = buf;
  klen = strlen (key);
  while (NULL != (spos = strstr (bpos, key)))
  {
    if ( (spos[klen] != '=') ||
         ( (spos != buf) &&
           (spos[-1] != ' ') ) )
    {
      /* no match */
      bpos = spos + 1;
      continue;
    }
    if (spos[klen + 1] != '"')
      return;                   /* not quoted */
    if (NULL == (endv = strchr (&spos[klen + 2],
                                '\"')))
      return;                   /* no end-quote */
    vlen = (size_t) (endv - spos) - klen - 1;
    *destination = malloc (vlen);
    if (NULL == *destination)
      return;                   /* out of memory */
    (*destination)[vlen - 1] = '\0';
    memcpy (*destination,
            &spos[klen + 2],
            vlen - 1);
    return;                     /* success */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static void
try_get_value (const char *buf,
               const char *key,
               char **destination)
explanation: The only non-const pointer-to-object usage in this function is the 'destination' parameter and the places where it is read or written. Rule 8.13 concerns whether pointers should point to const-qualified types; 'buf', 'key' and the local pointer variables (spos, bpos, endv) are already declared as const char * and therefore comply. The standard library calls (strstr, strchr, strlen, memcpy, malloc) are used in conventional ways and do not introduce additional pointer-to-non-const targets beyond the explicit 'destination' parameter. The listed fragments include the function declaration containing 'char **destination' and every site that dereferences or assigns through that non-const pointer; no other lines in the function present pointer-to-non-const issues requiring investigation under Rule 8.13.
